Bottle. Dark brown pour with little head. Vinous aroma with lots of alcohol. Phenolic and sweet, with brown sugar, chocolate, and earthy hops. Shared with catlover72, enjoyable but might be better with some time.

355 ml bottle @ OHaras, Tampere.
Pours a dark amber colour with a small white head. Aroma of yeast, dried fruits and some alcohol. Flavour of chocolate, yeast, dried fruits and some spices. Medium bodied with a fruity, yeasty finish. Good.
12 oz bottle.  Dark brown pour.  Virtually no aroma.  Flavor is dark fruit, spice, caramel, brown sugar.   Pretty good, but it doesnt break any new ground.

Bottle into tulip glass. Couldnt wait to try this one. Pour is deep mahogany at the bottom of the glass and slightly less dark as the beer reaches the top of the glass. Like peering into deep, murky water. The nose = wow! Intense smells of chocolate and caramel malt. Very sweet. Also, hints of cherry/plum are easy to pick out. Little hits of yeast and even less so of alcohol. Lacing is similar to a spiders web. Head was 1.5 fingers high and off white/light brown. Flavor is heavy in fruit (banana, raisin) in the forefront and pleasantly sweet. The malt characteristics also come through quite nicely, with caramel being the most present. The alcohol comes through like a crescendo, starting small and then finishing strong when a good size gulp is had. Reminds me of wasabi. This is a nicely done brew that doesnt disappoint.
Bottle.  Dark brown, slightly reddish, with beige head.  Raisin, prune, brown sugar, caramel, spice, and a light note of chocolate.  Very heavy and rich.  Quite nice, I would drink this again.
Bottle, not sure what year, probably 2010.  Poured a dark brown with nice head and lots of sediment.  Flavor was pretty standard for the style...spicy, dark fruits, deep and smooth.
deep brown thick pour, with a small but gorgeous head. aroma of brown sugar, sweet dark fruits. much of the same with the flavor and very slight alcohol at the end but wonderful.

From a 341ml bottle on 28/4/2011. Pours a cloudy amber with little head. Has a relatively subtle aroma of caramel, dark fruit, alcohol, and brown sugar. Starts off very sweet, with plums and caramel, which is followed quickly by a big dark chocolate bitterness, some spiciness, and a huge dollop of warming alcohol. It has some Belgian character to it in the flavour, but with less yeastiness. It definitely has a vinous character and tastes every bit of its 10.5 %. A  very good and quite challenging ale.

bottle aged six months. Pours earthy-brown. Aroma of yeast, caramel, dark fruit, alcohol. Taste is complex; some chocolate, nuts, caramel malt, earthy notes. Quite nice at first, but there is something a little off about the aftertaste. Nice warming alcohol feel. A good beer, but its not quite a great beer.

Very dark brown in color, with a very slim white head. The beer is moderately carbonated and is populated with notable yeast floaties. The aroma has a pronounced alcohol scent, followed by a caramel-like scent. Its a little light in intensity, however. After a number of sips, the yeast and phenolic spice come out in the aroma, but they take a little coaxing. The taste is sweet, yeasty, a little chocolaty, and very warming. The boozy warmth boarders on harshness at times, but the sweet, toasted malt flavor balance it. Full in body

11.5 fl oz bottle. Lots of buttery nuts, heavy berry fruit, and dark yeasty caramel cookies in this fairly straightforward quad. Poured only a light wispy layer of off-white head, good retention though, hazy thick body, and deep auburn in color. The aroma is lightly boozy with some wine and scotch qualities at the same time. Malted grains are also slightly too prominent. Also, berries, cherries, molasses, and light brown sugar. The body is also a bit hot, lightly yeasty, and heavy malt dominated. Light scotch up front and some light brown sugar mixed spices. More buttery molasses cookies and fruit through the middle, becoming more sugary in the finish. Not overly sweet or rich however. Overall, this probably needed to sit for several more months, as I expect some more complexities would show themselves. As it currently stands, this was a fairly standard strong quad that didnt quite peak my interest as I was hoping.
200th rating! awesome beer. flavours were everywhere, some alcohol warming but alcohol very well hidden. i really hope this comes back to the LCBO. amazing!

Bottle.  Pours a dark brown with a thin tan head.  Some sediment.  Aroma of bread, caramel.  Taste: Malty; bread, caramel, a bit yeasty, some earthy / herb bitterness.  Warming mouthfeel, very full-bodied.  Finishes with a herby bitterness, and some yeast.  Lots in there, very complex.  An interesting flavour experience!

Very nice indeed. This one was courtesy of Mane Liquors private stash for the good customers ! Glad to have had this. Very good one to sit for a while on. Dark amber pour with a small beige head. Aroma is raisins, caramel, brown sugar, fig. Flavours seem to be a nice mix of dark/dried fruits (raisins, plum, fig) and some sweet caramel malts. Very good indeed

A: The beer pours a dark amber color with some brownish notes and a thin layer of off-white head.

S: Starts off with alcohol and acrid roasted malts.  Surprisingly acidic with some dark fruits and dark candi sugars.  Definitely a green apple aroma and some spoiled chocolate.

T: Luckily the flavor is significantly better.  Sweet caramel and molasses with some bready malts.  A moderate roasted malt flavor and some alcohol, which becomes increasingly harsh as the beer warms up.  Dark chocolate provides some surprising bitterness.

M: Medium in body with a moderate level of carbonation.

O: I was really let down by this one.  Peche Mortel got me sort of excited about this brewery, but this was not enjoyable.

A nice quad.  It must be bottle condtioned cause it tasted like it is. Nice belgian yeastiness. Body is sorta lacking for a quad. Sweet and finishes slightly dry. Alot of carbonation for a quad. Pours dark brown but nothing like westy 12 or roch.10. definitely tasty. It lingers for quite a while and is satisfying to say the least. The difference between this and trappist like roch 10 or westy 12 is that it seems to be"trying" so hard to be the same. But just falls short. Nonetheless, a good beer.

Sweet raisin and orange aroma. Amber brown color with a bit of cloudiness. Sweet and bitter, the Rigor is backed with flavors of raisin, bread, orange, and booze. Very strong. Let it warm up a bit, but not too much or youll be facing a slap in the face with a boozy, fruity finish.

Bottle. Muddy brown appearance and large aromas of clove, orange peel and omnipresent alcohol. Very rich palate shows high-quality ingredients. Flavours of clove and cinnamon, plus watered-down milk chocolate.

Pours unclear brown with a slight red glow and a thing, quickly dissipating mocha head.  Aroma is not as strong as I expected given the style.  I smell roasted malts, candi sugar, and chocolatey caramel.  Taste is similar to the aroma, but stronger.  Lots of roasted malt, caramel, and a darker, chocolatey, almost coffee like note.  A little prune comes in toward the end.  I would like a little more sweetness on the finish to round things out... but this is all in all avery good beer.
good strong and delectable.  What strong browns should be. That good open air barnyard tasted that I love. Some good nutty notes with a slight earthiness. Slight leather and cereal. Need more. :/
One of the most complex quads Ive ever had, go canadians! malts are just very delicately layered in one of the most complex beers brewed

12oz bottle, Batch 0 notched on the label.  Definitely has some age on it of 1 year at the least, probably a fair bit more.  Served at cellar temperature.  Pours murky brown with a good light beige head that holds a foamy island and ring and leaves some nice sheets of lacing behind.  Aroma is dark fruits, particularly strong on the raisins along with some prunes, figs and black currants, yeast & bread, some caramel, toffee, brown sugar, and a touch of oxidation probably due to the fact that Dieu du Ciel is using screw-tops on their beers.  Very good to excellent strength.  Flavor is rich dark fruits, plums, figs, raisins, caramel, toffee, brown sugar, molasses, minimal to no hop presence, moderate to fair sweetness, lingering finish, alcohol is virtually absent.  Mouthfeel is medium to full, very creamy, low to medium carbonation.  This may very well be the best non-Belgian brewed Quad Ive ever had.  Wow.  Dieu du Ciel never ceases to amaze...just wish the price was better and they would stop using screw-top bottles!!!

Picked this bottle up somewhere in Ohio. Reviewed from notes.

Pours a moderately dark, nifty brown with a thin head. Nose brings a good amount of dark fruits, brown sugar, molasses, and a bit of booze. The taste melds dark fruits with some dark rum characteristics. Feel is nice. Fairly heavy with a good amount of alcohol warmth. Drinks fairly well, but is not their best offering.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 10-18-2010

Bottle. Heavy malt aromas of caramel, milk chocolate and nuts, light flowers and cooked orange for the hops, dough and broth for the yeast, with background notes of toffee, brown sugar, whiskey and dark dried fruits. Head is small, frothy, off-white with some spotty lacing and good legs and is almost fully diminishing. Color is muddy brown. flavor starts moderately to heavily sweet and lightly acidic, then finishes lightly bittersweet and acidic. Palate is medium to full, creamy wit a carbonation between soft and lively and finishes moderately alcoholic and a bit sticky. complex, well rounded and absolutely mouth filling, this is a very nicely composed Quadrupel. No surprise from Dieu du Ciel.

Nearly opaque mahogany color with a small head that quickly becomes a ring with a thin film island in the middle. Toffee, brown sugar, grapes, banana, and peppery hops in the aroma. The flavor adds more of everything, with the addition of alcohol and a kind of dry oakiness. A little boozy on the finish, but this works well with the dry sweetness. Full bodied with very calm carbonation. Has the mouthfeel of an aged barleywine, without being really chewy.

Bottle LCBO Brewery Promotion. Pours dark brown with a thin tan head. Fragrant aroma of roasted malts, dark chocolate and ripened fruit. Full bodied and lightly carbonated. Starts sweet but ends surprisingly dry. This is a very good beer - among my favourites - from a great brewery. I hope I can find a way to get a regular supply here in Ontario to last me through the winter.
Nice dark brown colour with an off white head. Taste of caramel and butterscotch with an aftertaste that is a little to bitter for this style. All in all a decent ABT.

UPDATED: JUN 19, 2014 @ tap at mikkeller bar. Pours dark amber with a light brown head. On the nose I got caramel malt, dark chocolate, dark dried fruits. Taste is the same along with some dark syrup, alot of dryness, ripe fruits, sourness and a belgian feel.

Presentation: It was poured from a brown 11.2oz bottle into a tulip glass. Info on the label includes its abv (10.5%) and a nice description of the beer.

Appearance: This beer has a dark murky body with some lighter mahogany and reddish brown highlights. From the pour I got a thin creamy off head. The small head quickly fades to a light film covering with a ring of foam at the edge of the glass. Lacing is slick and slides right down the glass.

Smell: It has a big fruity/estery aroma with hints of dark dried fruits like raisins and plum or prune. There are also notes of yeast and sweet bready/toasty almost chocolaty malt and as it warms I get some cherry notes too, along with mellow hints of its big 10.5% abv.

Taste/Palate: It starts with its good sweet malty base and then adds fruity and yeast notes to the mix. Everything from the aroma is picked up here and slowly fades off the tongue with some mellow peppery/spicy hops and boozy alcohol. Its full bodied and finely carbonated, which I feel is perfect for the style.

Notes: I absolutely love this beer and this brewery! This along with Péché Mortel and Aphrodisiaque have been standouts within there styles and they are some of my favorite beers.

Pours dark brown with a lasting creamy head and lacing.
Nose shows chocolate, liquorice, caramel, roasted malt and some Belgian phenols. A little fruit shows through, mainly raisins. The rich and diverse malt profile is a delight.
Flavours are syrupy sweet but theres nice amount of roasted malt to counter it. Alcohol is quite noticeable but not over the top. Similar malt profile and spicy character as in the aroma.
Carbonation is pretty high, but helps cut through the sweetness.
Dangerously drinkable stuff.

Bottle - Pours rosy brown and clear with a small light tan head. Smells sweet, with a bit of nail polish (that fades as it warms), lots of bready malt, clove, wheat, and ripe tropical fruit. Taste is fruity and bready, smooth with dark fruit and honey on the finish. Real smooth and pretty full-bodied. Yum.

Pours a hazy caramel hue with a tinges of ruby.  Forms a thin off-white head which quickly subsides to a thing ring around the glass.  Aroma is of sweet caramelized malts, and dark fruits; slight boozy and woody undertones noted also.  Nice and heavy malt profile right up front in the flavor, finishes through with a hot booziness that seems to deftly cut through the sweetness and balance the brew.  Full bodied on the palate, quite syrupy, although again, the high alcohol content curbs this and makes for a very enjoyable drinking experience.  Liquid bliss; well suited for many a  frigid Montreal evening.

341ml bottle.  Pours a hazy reddish brown with a beige head, and visible sediment.  Nose is big on caramel malts, dried fruit, banana, red wine, yeast, spice.  Mmm.  Flavours of dried cherry, woody notes, brown sugar, almond, prune.  Alcohol, and mild bitterness peeking through the sweet finish.  Big flavours, and LOTS of them.

Tasted on 1/18/11 from a 11.5oz bottle purchased at Sun Devil.  Pours cloudy brown with a tint of orange and a thick off-white head that slowly recedes to spotty and uneven lace, leaving plenty of lace on the inside of the glass as well.  The nose is sweet with a large amount of caramel malt, banana, chocolate, brown sugar, bruised red apple, and light cinnamon and clove.  The flavor is sweet with caramel, burnt brown sugar, and chocolate up front, moving to much more vinous flavors and bruised red apple on the middle, and finishing with more maltiness, and just a hint of burnt bitterness. The body is full with average carbonation and a long slightly bitter, vinous, and burnt brown sugar finish.
Murky brown pour with a brown head. Aroma is yeast, fruity. Taste is complex- yeast, dark fruits, bittersweet chocolate. Ok lacing. The taste gets better as it warms. Nice lacing.

UPDATED: SEP 10, 2013 pours dark hazy copper with a 3-finger beigeish head. powerful aromas of caramel, toffee, malts, ripened fruits and spices. taste is smooth with its sweetness (not too much though, just perfect) and full of caramel, plums, cranberry tartness, hint of chocolate, and some woodsy-smokey esters. very good quadrupel.
Bottle: pours dark brown with a thin, whispy head, aroma of dark fruit and Belgian sugar, taste is dark fruit, only mildly sweet, malty, a touch of the alcohol present.  Very nice.
Dark red beer with a creamy head. Smells of sweet malts, caramels, and bit of chocolate. Tastes of dried fruits. Alcohol finish is a little too strong.

Bottle. Clear deep mahogany with a small beige head that quickly fades to a small ring. Aroma of dark fruit, burnt sugar, bread and alcohol. The flavor is sweet malt and sugar with some tart earthy qualities and light alcohol. Medium to full body with mild carbonation. Pretty good beer, the expense will keep me from drinking this too often though.

Pours out dark brown, just a lace as head. Smell is roasted, a bit earthy sour-sweet fruit, chocolate, something less pleasant, a bit medicinal. Taste is overripe fruits, spices, malts, starts a bit sweet, ends pretty good modderated bitterness. Some chocolate inside. The medicinal thing is not at the taste, decent, but expected better.

UPDATED: JAN 26, 2011 Tastes very much like a tribute Quad. Nose releases faint whiffs of berries and sugary ethanol. Has a smooth body with some chocolate and fruits of the forest. Doesn’t quite meld togeher as a cohesive package. Another (moderately) over rated Dieu de Ciel to me. The Aphrodisiac is the only beer that has truly impressed me beyond being solid and workmanlike.

Pours a deep mahogany with ruby highlights.  The tan colored head atop was full, dense, and painted a nice thick lacing upon the glass.   Nose had sweet smelling elements of molasses and caramel, soft esters of Belgian yeast, and a slightly resiny hop influence as well.  Flavor nicely balances the different components..its somewhat sweet again with molasses and caramel, the hops keep it nicely crisp in the finish, and the somewhat tame yet evident flavors of the Belgian yeast bring the different components together quite nicely.   The alcohol is well hidden here as well and the body is relaxingly full. Nice balanced quad.

Really really top notch brew. Really enjoyed it. So so so smooth and delicious. No harshness in the aftertaste. Pours brown with a thin bubbly head on it. Great brew. One of the best i have had in a while.

From a bottle. Pours a brown/dark red color with no head. Smells of carmel, coffee and roasted nuts. The taste is almost like what an imperial brown ale would be. Aftertaste of some fruits, like raisins and figs. Almost remind me of what a hybrid of Dogfish Heads Raison DEtre and Indian Brown would be. I really enjoyed this beer. Would definitely have it again.

350ml bottle from Westlakeview Liquors. Great brew, best Canadian beer Ive had. Slightly cloudy ruby with a lasting hite head. Malty aroma with spice and fruit and a mineral touch. Big and sweet flavour, fruity with caramel, toffee, licorice and alcohol. Fine tasting quadrupel. On the sweet, but still one of the better Abt/Quad out there.

Appearance:  Pours a dark brown with a creamy white ring around the perimeter.

Aroma: Plum, raisin, vanilla, dark rum, dark sugar.

Taste:  Burnt sugar, raisin,spiced rum,burnt toast,sweet grape.

Mouthfeel:  Syrupy with lively,spicy carbonation.

Overall:  I love this beer, its so deeply rich and complex. Im not a cigar smoker, but I would file this under the cigar beer tag, if not an after dinner sipper.

Impressive in every respect.  Full, malty-brown sugar aroma, dark pour with a substantial dark head.  Taste of toasted malt, caramel, sweet grain, and maybe a hint of anise.  Stays big through the finish.  Reminds me of the darker Unibroue offerings with less of the candied fruit.  A great brew to finish an evening with.

11.5oz. Pours a deep brown with an off white head. A pretty boozy aroma with some sweet candied malt. Rich caramel and chocolate flavor with a slight bit of tart fruit and a significant amount of heat. Would like to age a bottlw the suggested amount and see were this goes.

Sampled from a 341ml bottle from the LCBO, poured into a Orval chalice. Pours a dark orange/ brown. The head is basically a white ring around the glass. Aroma is of carmel, spice and alcohol. Tastes much the same as the scent. Simply put, I enjoyed this brew.

Pours a dark walnut brown with a thin off-white ring for a head.  Aroma of Belgian yeast, dark fruit, and caramel.  Flavor is largely dark fruit, Belgian yeast, alcohol, and spice.  Nicely balanced.  Just a touch of alcohol on the back end.  Great beer!

It pours a cloudy brown color with a tan head that quickly disappears to a ring. It has a small amount of carb.

On the nose there is a dominating alcohol presence. Some faint roasted and chocolate notes and a little dark fruit.

The flavor is made up of roasted malt,chocolate. There is also some dark fruit present. It would actually be better if the high alcohol taste didnt take over as much. What can I say its unbalanced.

It finishes with a little sweetness and a burning sensation that lingers around. This is a lesser version of Dogfish head Indian brown ale. Not a bad beer even after you factor everything in. Not something you would session but still another good beer from a great brewery.
Brown/orange pour with creamy white head and lace. Sour roasted malt aroma. Sweet brown sugar with sour dried fruit. Foamy medium bodied beer.

12 oz bottle courtesy of savvy1982. Thanks. Pours a muddy amber-brown color with a small khaki head that soon fades to a fine film. The aroma is strong with mixed fruits, Belgian yeasts, leather and a whiff of hot alcohol. The flavor is similar to the nose with dark fruits, yeasts, hazelnuts, leather and tannins. The palate is full and creamy with lively carbonation. Finishes long with lingering biter nuts. Overall: A very tasty ale, very nice indeed.
Bottle.Dark rddish/brown colour with small beige head.Aroma is fruity of dried fruits and caramel.Flavor is mild rosted and warming good malty and smooth finish.

UPDATED: NOV 29, 2010 341mL bottle.  Pours cloudy dark red-brown with a thin off-white ring.  Aromas of dried fruit, caramel, roast and alcohol.  The flavour is sweet and strongly malt oriented; caramel, toast, dried fruit, maybe some banana, spices and alcohol.  Full bodied, soft carbonation, pretty sticky, a lot of heat from the alcohol and a lingering sweet finish.

12-oz bottle Philippes Lafayette, LA - Aroma: raisin, banana, sweet, caramel; Appearance: cloudy dark-brown color, off-white head, some laces;  Flavor: sweet, salty, malty, raisins, banana, plum, chocolate, caramel, rose-like alcohol; Mouthfeel: light to medium bodied, average carbonation; Overall: a wonderfully sweet and fruity malty belgian beer with a dry finish.  Not sure about the spices but the alcohol is nicely mellow and warming.

Pours a red brown with a short lived head. The aroma is sweet, molasses, dark fruits, syrup, licorice, good. The flavour follows suit pretty much bang on. The mouth feel is carbonated but still smooth and lets the flavours sit on your tongue just right. Great stuff from a great brewery.
Pours small head that retains. Dark brown. Huge alcohol flavour at the start. Smoother as it goes. Very similar to other abt I have had. Overall very good.

Ive decided to finally open a 4-pack ive been saving for a little over a year under the staircase ans i was very pleased!  A lot more round and generous than the younger version.  A rich dark chocolate and caramel taste and a hint of oakiness with a nice alcohol finish along with was seems to be a fig taste.

The lack of aroma is convincingly compensated by the nice complex warm flavors... quite simply a beautifully crafted nectar!
Big full flavoured beer. this really packs a ounc in terms of both aroma and flavour with the 10.5% alc certainly making it presence felt. Impressive winter time sipping beer.
Dark amber.  Spicy banana, dark fruit, smoke, and alcohol in the aroma.  Overall sweet with some alcohol at the end.  Quite good.

Sample at brewpub. Pours a hazy brown with a dense, beige head. Aroma is slightly boozy but deep with dried fruits, bread and caramel. Full bodied taste with similar notes and a somewhat oily mouthfeel. Pretty high carbonation. Warming finish with some breadiness. Really wonderful.

UPDATED: DEC 4, 2010 This beer is quite good for the style. I am impressed, for a quad it is a little light but I really enjoy this. I would recommend this one to be drank not extremely cold, just a bit cool
Incredible! The dark brown color is not nearly as dark as I like, but the taste is exceptional.  So far, I would rate it as one of my top three beers!

UPDATED: DEC 10, 2010 Tasted on tap at the International Tap House in St. Louis, Missouri.  Dark burgundy appearance.  Medium body with an alcoholic flavor present but not not too strong.  Strong hint of raspberry with a Belgian candy sugar flavor.  Flavor is pretty fruity with the characteristic candy sugar flavor.  Quite sweet but still a good Quadrupel.

Ill ad this to my list of 5s. This brewery is incredible. Alcohol hits you at first. I taste a little wheat in there. I love that they put this in 12oz. bottles. Very sweet with dark fruits. fabulous!

Bottle. Pours muddy red brown, opaque with tan head, lacing the glass. Sweet aromas, caramel, honey, bread, cereal with maybe a hint of grass plus some brandy. Medium-full body: raisins, dried fruit, sweet caramel, lightly toasted malt and burnt toffee. Finish of strong alcohol and abbey yeast.

Pours a cloudy brown with off-white head that quickly dissipates. Good lacing. Aroma is candy, yeast, and spice. Lovely aroma. Taste is sweet, malty and yeasty with some fruit. Lightly carbonated. Some lingering bitterness. Full bodied. Very enjoyable beer.

12oz bottle-Thanks decaturstevo-pours a rich off white head and dark copper color.  Aroma is medium malt-roasty/toffee, fruit, musty.  Taste is dark fruit-prune/date, sweet dark malt-molasses, spice/earthy hops bite.
A generally quite tasty beer, with a strong roasty chocolate flavor profile.  The aftertaste is a little on the bitter side, though, compared to the initially rather non-bitter flavor.

Aroma of raisin, fig, candi sugar and roasted caramel. Appearance is dark brown with tan head. Flavor matches the nose, with nice rum alcohol in the finish. Palate is creamy and bubbly. A nice North American quad, but doesnt compare to the Belgians in mouthfeel.

Extremely complex and extremely strong. Very impressive effort from Dieu du Ciel. The amount of flavours and their strenght and the dimensions of the alcoholic bite will surely surprise many! Good beer.

341mL bottle. Bottled 4/2010
Hazy reddish-brown body with small, but thick and persistent head of beige foam.
Mellow sort of aroma, that certainly seems to have rich potential; treacle, clove, dried and dark fruits, alcohol.
Texture is beautifully thick and silky. Medium carbonation with tremendous length.
Seriously intensly rich flavour; lots of berry fruits, plum, mollasses, fig, sultana, almost Christmas cake like. Finish is spicy, with a hint of phenolic bitterness and plenty of warming brandy-like booziness.
Very rich, sweet Belgian ale with plenty of flavour, and alcohol. Certainly has the complexity, but missing the finesse that makes a great Belgian into an extraordinary Belgian.

2010 Vintage: pretty good. An interesting combination of relatively subdued Belgian strong ale notes (cola, roast, fruitcake) with a fairly aggressive and alcohol led structure that packs a bit bitey, spicy, hot punch on the finish. Surprisingly fizzy too. No doubt this would age ok.
Bottle from Monument Liq. in Concord, CA. Pours a cloudy brown and smells of dark fruits. Tastes of figs and raisins. Smooth on the palate with just a hint of alcohol taste. Great beer!!

Poured 11 oz bottle into a trappist glass.  Aroma of caramel, sweet dark fruits, like raisin.  Appearance is beautiful brown with tan head that does not stick around.  The taste is very complex, and alcohol like port is right up front...a little too much, but the finish is long and the alcohol flavors disspates through the finish.  Flavors of toffee, bread, and cocoa are noted.  Palate is full body, creamy with soft carbonation and a long finish.  Overall a very nice brew, but one that you want to have a clean palate to detect all the flavors behind the alcohol.  I imagine aging this beer for a couple of years would do it well...even though this one was 6 months old.

Dark brown colour, moderate carbonation. Beige head that dissipates quickly. Malty aroma with touches of fruit. Strong caramel flavour, and an overwhelming presence of ABV. Its good, very good, but that alcohol is strong.

11.5oz. bottle.  Sweet, fruity, spicy aroma, heady and rich with notes of toffee, licorice, cinnamon, red grape, plum and vanilla.  Opaque dark reddish-brown in color with a fine, lasting head.  Rather complex flavor profile, quite malty, spicy and bittersweet with aspects of dried, dark fruit, nut, milky chocolate, bready, doughy yeast, clove and features some lightly vinous touches, earthiness and medicinal alcohol in the background.  Palate is smooth, low in effervescence and warming, body is very full.  Really enjoyable.

341ml bottle. Pours a murky dark red-brown, with a large, lasting beige head, which leaves excellent lacing. The aroma is a pleasant combination of coffee and port, with some sweet caramel hints. A moderate level of pine resin hops are present to begin, but are soon overcome by a truckload of sweet malt flavours, with caramel and toffee particularly noticeable. The finish is dark, with lots of bitter espresso malt. A quality beer indeed; I thoroughly enjoyed this.
Nose of heavy toffee, port, oak. Broad fat feel, decent carb. Taste is alcohol, follows nose.

Bottle. Amber with some floating bits. Beige head fades to a rim. Complex malty aroma has dried fruit and berries, dark sugars, nuts, blood oranges, mild spices. Taste: toffee, prunes and plenty of spices - white pepper, ginger, mace - and sherry. Alcohol is really rather prominent. Mouthfeel is only slightly syrupy, perhaps lightened by a nice amount of carbonation. Fruity sweetness and alcohol yield to spices and almonds in a long finish.

Bottle. Pours a cloudy dark mahogany with creamy coffee coloured head,  Good lacing. Aromas is very sweet. Usual suspects dark toffee and dark fruits. Some spiceness is apparent also. Flavours are pretty similar. Sweet dark malt and stone fruits. Spicy dry finish. Nice beer

UPDATED: OCT 13, 2016 ***re-review Oct 13, 2016 - last bottle from my 2009 or 2010 stash***

Dammit if this isnt still really good albeit showing some oxidation. This bottle basically has not moved in 6 years with almost zero temperature variance while remaining in total darkness. Its from the same batch as the original review. 
Still holds on to its former sweet aromatic nature, with the brown sugar ruling, chocolate and raisins holding solid. Slightest of the cardboard but it only adds to the awesomeness and long lasting complexity. The taste has improved with the harshness of the alcohol and sharpness mellowing out with dementia of old age. The yeast has held up to a higher level than expected, molasses, caramel etc still holding strong minus the raisins. The alcohol still exists along with a bit of sharpness and spice. Has a bit of dryness. Not much improvement on the taste as the changes for the better and worse have seemingly cancelled the effects of each other out. Now that is how one correctly cellars a beer! Well worth the wait if not just to enjoy it once again. ****
Original review: 9/26/2010
Rich brown brew with a very nice light brown creamy solid cap leaving permanent lacing. Great aroma - sweet and powerful. Loads of brown sugar, molasses, caramel, plum, spices (nutmeg, licorice), faint wood, light earthiness, candied orange rind. Taste: burnt sugar, dulling yeast feel, raisins, chocolate (cool!) - I get this on every sip, sugar, intense sharp aftertaste. alcohol, candy (???which???). Too much alcohol peered at me so I think my other bottles will sit for a year +. Alcoholic bit in the middle gives way to light bitterness and an odd chocolate / plum / burnt sugar aftertaste. Decent brew but not a fave mainly due to the alcohol (which came out strong after I let this sit in my glass).

Looks amazing in a goblet with a thick viscous head that slides effortlessly down the sides of the glass, carried by a strong alcohol current. Tawny cloudy brown with a strong raisiny brown sugar aroma, the round mouthfeel is enough to wow you on its own. Starts slightly tart with a thick sweetness that is quickly tempered by a slight earthy bitterness. The sweetness returns quickly though and lasts long into the aftertaste with the alcohol burn only creeping in at the very end. Spicy cinnamon and black pepper appears mid swallow. Heavy handed; but in a good way.

Bottled from Systembolaget a while ago
Dark amber with a small off-white head.
Fruity, spicy and nutty in both aroma and flavour.
Pretty sweet with notes of brown sugar.
Pretty low bitterness and a warming alco-feel.

Bottle (2009) and served in my other Unibroue tulip: Brownish hue with amber, purple and coppery highlights topped by a small but lasting head and left spotty lace upon the glass, some oily legs. The aroma has notes of dark candi sugar syrup, plum pudding, prune juice, apricot jam, marizpan, stinging alcohol, earthy minerals and some peaty like smoke, clove, white pepper, and woody finesse. Smells like a a Wee Heavy meets a Abbey Ale, and I like it!  The taste starts with heavy layers of sweet malt sugars, some candied fruit twang and a sharp alcohol and spicy character that kept it from becoming cloy and overbearing. The constant earthy tones added complexity and roundness. This is a full forced reminder of the best of the Abbey Strong Ales but as a character that I will once again described as something more akin to a Wee Heavy or Scotch Ale I found intriguing. The mouth feel is full bodied and aggressive with a woody finish. This is the 2nd or 3rd Dieu du Ciel I found to be wonderful and slightly twisted surprising, I love it and recommend you age some for yourself.

The beer pours a medium to dark amber with a small beige head.  The creamy bubbles faded quickly, but its still a nice looking beer.  The aroma has a fair bit of booze but also lots of complexity with notes of brown sugar, toffee, raisins, rum, peaches, mint, grapes and warm bread.  The taste also has a good deal of booze and is a mite sticky sweet, but the sugary malt flavors are terribly pleasant and the alcohol provides happy warmth.  The finish has some mild bitterness, not really enough to rein in the sweetness but who cares when the flavor is this nice?  Mouthfeel is smooth, full and somewhat sticky.  Carbonation is relativley low, likely exacerbated by the age of the bottle (twist-offs?  how do they work?).

Bought in Quebec at Depanneur de la Rive and aged six months - perfect. It has a complex, sweet and malty, almost berry or currant aroma.. The color pours a brown, opaque amber that is bubbly in appearance with a soft white head. The flavor is rich and sweet maltiness with some boozy and caramel notes. The body is medium to thick with a nice mouthfeel.

Cloudy redish brown with a thin with layer as a head. Aroma is caramel, chocolate, bread, alcohol, fruits. Full body, with low carbonation. First is chocolate, caramel, then a fruity aftertaste. Classic ! Another amazing beer from Dieu du Ciel.

Bottle on 08/29/2010. Somewhat cloudy amber body with a medium creamy off-white head. Big bready, toasty and caramel aroma. Sweet caramel and bready flavor with toffee notes. Medium full body with moderate carbonation.

Biege small head on top a misty murky red ruby pour aromas dark fruit raisin yeast brown sugar sweet cherries alcohol prune flavours absorbing bitter raisin prune yeast brown sugar cherry mild alcohol a salty taste but no harm adds to the flavour good quadruple finish dark fruit good malt tastes strong bitter slightly salty lasting aftertase very classy

Served in a trappist glass at Dieu du Ciel in Montréal. 10.5%. Dark chocolatey-brown pour with a foamy tan head, medium retention. Aroma is intense sweet toasted malt, toffee, chocolate. An array of flavours on the palate, chocolate toffee malt, fruity blackcurrant and berries, a yeasty spiciness, hint of cinnamon. Finishes with a tinge of bitterness that lingers with this perfect balance of taste sensations. Absolutely superb.
A king among Canadian-made beers.
Neat Label,  Honey orange nose.  Very Flat carbonation.  Too Sweet for my taste, not enough hop or carbination balance.  Boozy, which is ok but needs other balance.
Amber red body with short head. Alcohol, dark fruits and sugar in the aroma but not necessarily in that order. Same in the taste, comes across smooth and warming and very drinkable.

UPDATED: OCT 4, 2010 ** Re-Rate after Draught ** Fantastic Quad from DDC. A very respectable contender in the Quad category.. deep and rich with a nice low gas which allows the flavors to build and integrate. Strong woods and sweet balance the alcohol very well. This is a very drinkable beverage. Happy that is coming to the LCBO. Now I can drink the ones I have been storing 

Bottle. Hazy, dark reddish brown pour with a short tan head that quickly settles to surface cover. Aroma is a little vinous and spicy with notes of toffee, raisins, candy sugar, wood and hints of resiny pine and berries. Flavour has strong toffee, port, raisin and spice notes, with hints of oak, licorice, maple syrup and alcohol. Medium bodied with low carbonation and a lingering sweet, spicy finish that shows a bit of alcohol warmth. Overall this is a very good quad, surprisingly light and easy to drink yet still a decidedly big beer. Another great one from D.D.C.

UPDATED: SEP 9, 2010 This is a revision of my rating from 2010-08-17. On tap at Dieu du Ciel, served in a tulip. Pours clear reddish brown with a frothy tan head. The head fades to a thin remnant but leaves a small amount of fine lace as it does. The nose is complex and quite inviting. Beautiful aromas of caramel, chocolate, candi sugar and port, along with alcohol, fruit, flowers, yeast, vanilla and some spice. The flavour is driven by complex malts: medium sweet throughout with a tiny hint of hops and a good dose of alcohol. The finish is long and malty. On the palate, this beer is medium-full in body with a smooth, creamy texture and soft carbonation with fine bubbles. Overall, this is an amazing abt, definitely one to be savoured. It is well assembled and it is hard to believe it weighs in at 10.5% ABV. The malts are elegant and complex. This beer is excellent on tap, but the bottle version scored higher, probably because it was aged for 16 months. 2010-09-04

UPDATED: NOV 11, 2010 love this stuff. pours brown with medium head. Big caramel notes and bready/yeasty notes. nice malts and chocolate notes as well.  beautiful stuff on the nose. some chocolate and has a reninous quality on the palate. big rich round full bodied flavours and amazingly balanced for the alcohol percentage. this is a great brew! fantastic stuff.

Into a goblet....

The aroma is pure Brett-funk, just this side of vinegar. Nutty malt, brown sugar. Alcohol comes through for sure. Not entirely pleasant at first until it mellows out.

The appearance is flat caramel brown. Not a lick of head. Thick and chunky looking. Good color, but a little flat.

The flavor is dried fruits (raisins, dates) with a conspicuous alcohol burn. Very funky. Tobacco ashes. Some brown sugary sweetness, like an English ale. Leather. By all means, take it out of the fridge a half hour before drinking.

The palate is pure alcohol burn, then a fizzy, milky finish. Burns just a tad. Overall, its a decent Belgian dubbel. A little sweet, not quite dark. Serious tobacco finish. Better when warmed up.

Bottle. 11.7 oz. Drank this bottle on my last night alone in the Bryn Mawr apartment. Pours a deep, cloudy mahogany brown with a two-finger, creamy off-white head. Aroma of Belgian candied sugar, roasted malts, cinnamon, and slight hints of chocolate and licorice. Full bodied with a crisp, sweetly-sticky mouthfeel. Finishes strong, with a smooth boozy burn. Excllent quad.

From bottle. Murky hazelnut brown with a thin white head and lace. Strong flavour, spiced with yeast and malt aroma. Flavour is of malt, hint of yeast and brown sugar. Slightly spiced. The beer has a great texture, lovely tasting beer.

UPDATED: MAR 22, 2012 Bouteille 341 ml. Cuvée Juin 2010. 10.5%. Couleur brune foncé, brouillé. Mousse beige fugasse. Arome de caramel, dherbe de prunes et dépices. En bouche, des notes dalcool, de malt, de caramel. Bonne mais je laisserai vieillir la prochaine. 
Mise à jour vieillie 5 mois, cuvée juin 2010: Arôme de levures, dherbe, dalcool. En bouche, une douceur...notes de prunes, chocolat doux, levures belges. Une finale qui réchauffe, réconfortante. Très bonne
Dégustation comparative le 22 mars 2012. Cuvée juin 2010: Presque aucune mousse. Arôme de levures, prunes.En bouche, notes dalcool, finale plus amère. Pas top. Cuvée octobre 2011: Belle mousse persistante beige. Arôme de levure, malt, raisins cuits. En bouche, fraîche, agrumes, un peu de chocolat. Bonne.

341ml bottle. Pours a nice dirty, cloudy brown with little brownish head that leaves almost no lace. Big brown sugar nose with stewed fruit and a good solid roasty sweetness. Big, fat, malty sweet finish. A perfect summer seasonal.

Aging one of these currently but thought Id try one now too. Pours a dark brown / mahogany colour with a nice big beige head. Aroma is of dark fruit; raisins and dates with some roasted malts and a slight boozy scent. Taste is sweeter up front with the fruit most noticeable then becomes a little more bitter with some alcohol notes, quite nice. Full bodied, average carbonation and smooth on the palate. Very good beer, not my favourite Dieu du Ciel but quite good.
12oz bottle.  Aroma of spice, roasted malts, and raisin.  Flavor of sweet malt, a little spice from the yeast, a slight hint of dark fruits.  Full bodied and nice texture.  Very good beer.

Pours a hazy dark caramel color.  Taste has hints of fruit and dark malt.  Creamy off-white head.  A little hot alcohol taste.  This beer is delicious and is just another great offering from this brewery.

Jadis en fût mais cette fois-ci en bouteille.  Le liquide est brun et la mousse épaisse et dense ne reste que quelques secondes.  Le nez est dominé par un malt riche qui transpire le toffee et le chocolat.  Présence modérée à forte de fruits comme le raisin, la cerise et les pruneaux.  Lalcool se fait doux et permet lémergence dune petite pointe poivrée.  Pas de houblons dans les arômes.  Au goût, aucun égarement possible : les saveurs sont très similaires aux parfums.    En bouche, on peut dire que la richesse du malt donne beaucoup de douceur et que lalcool ressenti compense labsence damertume de houblons.  Présence dune effervescence notable.  La texture du liquide est somme toute crémeuse et possède une densité moyenne.  La finale est réconfortante dalcool et de petits fruits foncés.  En résumé, cette bière est dangereuse et doit être bue durant les soirées chaudes et humides!

Bottle from Bruisin in Asheville.  Pours cloudy, muddy amber brown with small but solid light beige head.  Looks lovely and intense, and it delivers upon this promise. Nose is complex malts: toffee, caramel, dark red fruits, including the skins.  Taste has an almost tannic quality.  Sweet but not overbearing.  Really lovely.  By far one of the best non-Belgian takes on the style.  I may buy a few more of these to age for a while.  Great.
Bottle from Cavie and Sprinkle.  Brown pour with a tan head.  Aroma is alcohol, brown sugar, cinnamon, and roasted malt.  Taste is sweet spice, malt, dark fruit, and too much alcohol.

Bottle poured a clear reddish brown with a small lasting tan heads. Aromas of carmel, pepper, plum, dates, toffee, light earthiness and light cocoa. Palate was medium to full bodied and smooth. Flavors of toffee, carmel, plum, fig, light earthiness and light cocoa with a smooth lingering dark fruit finish.

Bottle courtesy of Sprinkle.  Clouded murky brown color.  Aroma is all kinds of dark malts, clay, peat moss and wood.  Dark fruits are on the flavor. Taste is wonderfully smooth with raisins, plums, wood, earth and aging flavors.  Not bad at all!

Denna trappist-inspirerade ölen har lite surölsdoft över sig. Vätskan är ganska tunn och det skummar inte nåt särskilt. Trots att den är tunn, värkar den mycket oljig när man smakar på ölen. Själva smaken är också rätt intressant. En blandning av äppelcider, lite kola och malt. Någon särskilt eftersmak har den inte, men det är en mycket trevlig liten belgare som med sina 10 % är lagom het.

This bottled brew from a bottle shop poured a large sized head of foamy fine to medium sized bubbles that were mostly lasting and left behind a strongly carbonated hazy with fine particulate and a thick foamy lacing. The aroma was hoppy vinous and brown malt. The mouth feel was tingly at the start and at the finish. The thick flavor contained notes of vinous and hops. Delicious and one I would certainly like to have again.

335 ml bottle (Pikkulintu, Helsinki)
5 at first a slightly alcoholic aroma - a touch of dark fruits, some hint of roast as it warms
4 deep ruby or cherry red, ring head.
6 rich roast, good brun immitation, but a touch of glue in the retronasals. slightly alcoholic, 
3 crisp carbonation, tingles the tongue. Finish is a touch pencil sharpenings. 
12 had after Route des Epices and Dernier Volonte, and this was clearly the weakest of the batch.

Bottles from Capones and Smiths.  Pours hazy deep brown w 3f off tan head.  Nose is malty, with brown sugar, fig, tart cherry, some funk.  Tastes malty, with figgy raisiny fruit, semi-sweet brown sugar, prune, plum, very complex, and with a fruity finish.

Bottle, thanks to presario. Pours a hazy reddish brown with a delicate almond head. Aroma is dark caramel, molassess, cobwebs, fig paste. Flavours of figs, rye, dark caramel, and white pepper. Finish is warming but not harsh. A terrific sipper. Im happy Trevor gave me two bottles, as Im interested in seeing where this will go after a few years in the cellar.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text:
341ml bottle 
10.5% ABV 
I tried this beer on May 20, 2010 at "The Beerbistro" in Toronto, Ontario, Canada.  The beer poured a very dark brown, almost metallic in colour with a very thin white head.  The aroma was roasted malt, molasses, and plenty of dark fruit.  The mouthfeel was full-bodied, slightly creamy, with medium carbonation.  The flavour was sweet malt, candy sugar, and dark fruit.  Exceptional.

Unique beer with a high ABV. This beer is outstanding, the flavor is just priceless. Brew on-tap at the microbrewery. Think head, full body and thik thik beer. This beer is like no other. A must try, oh yea!

Sampled on BQ2010. Bottle on the RV. Pours a dark brown with some sediment evident and sticking to the side of my solo cup (blasphemy!). Aroma of dark fruits and alcohol. Some sweetness to the aroma. Mouthfeel is thick, sticky, and syrupy. Flavor of caramel and maple syrup dominate.

Bottle. Nose is sweet chocolate, caramel, and figs with a light fruitiness and some alcohol. Beautiful lacing from a thin white head on a brown to amber body.  Flavor is dominated by alcohol with some light malt notes and  a sweet finish. Very hot with an almost solventy alcohol character. Medium bodied. Could be that this was an off bottle, as my rating is the lowest for this beer and it is a promising offering from a terrific brewery.

Bottle. Pours a hazy reddish/brown with a creamy off-white head that left good retention and lacing. Sweet and fruity aroma with caramel, dark fruit, raisins, figs and alcohol. Flavor was moderately sweet with rich caramel malts, dark raisins, chocolate, dark fruit, figs, alcohol and had a medium plus body with a dry finish.

Bottle, Pours a clean walnut w/ a fizzy off-white head, aroma is dried fruit, toffee, and booze, flavor is immediate dried fruits followed by a twinge of bitterness and a then a warm alcohol fade, palate is smooth, rich, and velvety, great representation of the style
Bottle. Dark amber colour with a beige head. Aroma is dry, dried fruits. Flavour is sweet, alcohol, hop, malt,licorice, hop, caramel. Bitter finish. Full body. Powerful beer.
Has a dark brownish color with a white foam head. The aroma has notes of alcohol, nuts, and spice. The taste burns a little at first but goes down easy. Very smooth

Dark, dark brown. Has an off-white head, mostly lasting. Aroma is yeasty, coffee, laqurice, malt, soft. Flavor starts heavy sweet and finish sweet and only light bitter, long duration. Soft. Creamy texture, soft carbonation. Nice way to die...

lakrids smell(do not like in beer)black, brown foam, light sweetness, medium bitterness, lightly sour, salty, medium body, creamy, soft carbonation, long finish, nice beer but I do not like lakrids in beer.

Poured a nice opague dark brown. Bubbly head lasted nicely. Chocolate and licorice, clean and slightly oil-ish on the nose. Medium to heavy mouthfeel with phenol chocolate and alcoholy cherry cordials. This is a complex beer. It lingers nicely too... maybe this one would grow on me. Is there any doubt that when the company says theyre inspired by the Trappist beers of Belgium, they mean the top Rochefort beers in particular?

11.5 oz bottle from the old Bier Stein. Poured a nice mahogany with a fairly small head and very little lacing. Aroma was very complex, with hints of raisin, prune, brown sugar, candi sugar and a bit of grape. Flavor was of a similar stripe, but with the toffee and caramel youd expect from the "brown ale" label that they put upon this beer. There is also almost no trace of alcohol, which is incredibly unusual for a beer at 10.5%. Very enjoyable brew, as Ive come to expect from these wacky Canucks. Also excellent label art. And remember to drink it warm, it gains in complexity as the temperature rises.

Bottle at beerbistro. Rich beer with a deep and complex fruit sweetness. Not all sweet up front, but an undercurrent running through the beer. Quite nice, had as an after dinner beer, and was excellent. Tons of sediment in bottle too. Another good one from Dieu De Ciel!

UPDATED: MAY 15, 2016 Originally rated 6 years ago, a long needed update. A: licorice, red fruits, spicy App: hazy reddish brown thick white head and excellent lacing. T/p: full body with sweet and medium long finish. Moderate high carbonation. O: cant feel the high abv at all which nice. Its somewhat spicier than in my memories. Great complexity.

Slightly hazy copper/brown with thin head.  Aroma of sweet candy sugar, ripe fruit.   Taste starts mild, then explodes in the back of the palate with tangy malt sweetness which melds into peppery alcohol mixed with a woodsy and very slighlty piney hop and quickly blends into a hot dry finish.  Very nice, great food beer.

Gigantic sweet body and slightly warm alcohol steals some of the show, but still an exercise in class and true Belgian character. Year old bottle at Bar Volo was enjoyed in snifter style glass. Looks really decent with a hazy deep ruddy brown and a ring of off-white cap from delicate pour (more vigorous pouring produces a tall lacy cream color cap but reduces the peppery carbonation making the beer seem smoother.)  Aromas of faint fruit but taste explodes into fruit and spice a bit like Rochefort  Tropical fruit and banana rooty spice and citrus. - long finish of spice and hop and complex fruit, palate is full and almost a little sticky sweet. Hell of a beer to try and age I would imagine. Thank you DDC!
Dark pour. Initial bourbon and molasses mouth feel. Dry hop finish was a pleasant surprise. High abv content is very noticeable here. Rated 4/9/10

Bottle. Deep murky red-brown body, medium buff head. Nose of toffee, bread dough, tangy caramel, herbal, bitter esters, and alcohol. Nice doughy, yeasty sip, with sharp alcohol that enhances notes of red wine, cola, and sticky sugars. Spritzy finish with sweet bread dough, chocolate, dark fruits, spice, and alcohol. Diverse, assertive, and quite pleasing.

Small, fast disappearing yellowish head over reddish dark-brown beer; Fruity-sweet nose, with lots of caramel, molasses even. Dark fruits like plums and figs in the background and quite some alcohol. Sweet, fruity again, with restsugars, caramel, dark candico, alcohol and fusels. Overripe pear and banana flavours; dark raisins to finish. Very balanced, if it werent for the alcohol, Id call it even timid (for its massive ABV). Warming up, a bit of (milk)chocolate. Certainly very good, but it has not the complexity of a Westvleteren.  Un grand merci à Dany!

Bottle pour to Trappist glass gives dark caramel color with brief thin tan head.  Aroma fairly typical with fruits.  Taste dark fruits, chocolate, malt.  Alcohol is quite apparent.  Hops subdued with minimal aftertaste.  Medium bodied with mildly thick texture

Another nice Abt but for the price you might as well drink a true Trappist.

Deep red brown. A very Belgian bread and fat banana and lemon aroma. Super thick and sweetish. It possesses a lovely depth with  cereal roasty loveliness and maybe the slightest hint of resinous hoppage. An excellent beer but not exactly what it claims to be.

Reddish brown with a light tan head.  Bubbles stick to sides of chalice.  Smells of dark fruits, dark sugar, a little nutty, a little syrupy.    Faint "bubblegum".  Medium to heavy mouthfeel. Plum, dark sugar, a wee bit of funkiness.  Finishes sweet.  Very tasty.  Should buy a few to cellar and whenever available.

11.5 oz. bottle from Jungle Jims.  Pours a hazy reddish-brown with a finger-thick, creamy beige head that settles nicely on top of the beer.  Aroma of sweet caramel malts, candi sugar, Belgian yeast, raisins, dates, figs, wood, dust, and vanilla.  Flavor of candi sugar, sweet caramel malts, Belgian yeast, lactic acid, rainwater, flat root beer, and cardboard.  Sweet, bitter, acidic, malty, fruity, and woody, with a dry finish.  Medium-bodied, with fizzy carbonation.  Complex and well-balanced, nice beer, but there are plenty of better quads out there.

12oz bottle from BOTW. Poured into a snifter, the color is a muddy brown with wispy white traces across the surface.  Aroma is more interesting than I expected. Sweet and fruity with a bit of vanilla. Flavor is much the same, with a hint of oaky vanilla and caramel. Some spices... very nice.

bottle pours light reddish brown with a medium off white head.  Aroma is sugary, dark red fruit, some bready yeast.....smells so inviting.  Flavor is rich caramel malt, bready sweet malts, green raisins, lots of dark candy sugar.  Very complex and delicious.

2009 Vieillie 1 an et dégustée le 11 avril 2010: Couleut brune rougeatre et tres peu deffervescence. Légere mousse frivole. Aromes beaucoup moins présents qua sa sortie, mais elle a toujours des odeurs de jambon fumée et dalcool. En bouche, elle a toujours des notes de jambon fumée et dalcool, mais plus modérée. Elle se boit plus facilement et est plus intéressante . Quelques notes de petits fruits rouge apparaissent. Le caramel commence a faire son apparition, mais je crois que cette biere peut encore vieillir 1 ou 2 ans pour nous offrir son maximum.
341ml bottle at Chancey Smiths, London.  Reddish pour with minimal head.  Dry, yeasty aroma.  Body is sweet and thick, with flavours of dark fruits, with a pleasing dry finish.

330mL bottle, pours dark brown with an amber tinge and a medium off-white head. Yeast, toffee and caramel malts on the nose - though not overpowering. Complex flavour of brown sugar, toffee, yeast and dried fruits, with not much sweetness. Excellent.

Bottle from Whole Foods. Pours a deep, hazy brown with a thin, brown head. Aroma is big on yeast with plenty of dark, dried fruits in the background. The flavor carries over these qualities, giving a sweet and sour impression. Medium/full bodied. I enjoyed this one.

UPDATED: APR 3, 2010 Bottle. Cloudy brown body with ruby highlights. Off-white, dense head slowly diminishing to bubbly pools. The sweet malts and sugars dominate the aroma. Notes of candy sugar, cotton candy, overripe dark fruits and licorice. Slight hint of charred wood, mustiness and figs. The flavor is heavily sweet, lightly bitter and lightly acidic. It finishes moderately to heavily sweet, lightly to moderately bitter and lightly to moderately acidic. Taste is a blend of sweet licorice, plums and figs. Medium to full body, velvety texture that turns slightly chalky the more you drink. Moderate to fizzy carbonation. Very enjoyable quad with plenty of flavor. It wore on me by the end, however, especially the mouthfeel which should have been cleaner.

UPDATED: APR 14, 2010 Bottle. Pours opaque brown with a orange tint. No head. Aroma was very mild... sour apple, grapefruit, citrus, caramel, alcohol. Taste: caramel malts, bitter chocolate, yeast, fruit, alcohol... however, it was a little flat. Overall good/decent. I would like to try another that isnt flat... I thought the potential was there.

bottle - Pours hazy dark amber with a lingering, one finger, off-white head.  The aroma is yeasty and a little on the sour side.  The flavor is sweet and malt rich with caramel, dark fruit, and spices.  Very enjoyable.

Bottle. Brown/dark reddish colour with a beige head. Aroma: Malty, lighty spicy/fenolic, apples, figs, berries, almonds, lightly roasted. Flavor: Malty, sweet & vinous, apples, berries, figs, plums, almonds, caramel, chocolate, alcohol, a bit salty, lightly spicy, lightly roasted. Sweet, but with a drier ending. Nice, but definitely a sipper.

Bottle. Murky brown with small white head that lasts. Aroma of brown sugar, molasses, caramel, booze. Taste is big chocolate and caramel malts with nice crisp ending. Very sweet but not in a bad way. Grows on you big time, just finished the brew and want to crack another. Medium bodied and not too heavy, especially for 10.5abv.

12oz Bottle, purchased at Zenos Pub - State College, PA. Caramel, brandy, and plums come out in the nose, surprisingly subtle for a beer at 55F. Pours a hazed ruby, with a fluffy finger of rose and cashew. Flavors are classic quad. Bristling rich and fresh sugars, a bit of perceived candied cherries, and some saccharin-heavy milk chocolate sauce. Boozy and brave. Aggregated pilsner malt minerals. The lifting carbonation carries some of the flavors around, but for the density and weight this beer doesnt quite have the je ne sais quoi Im looking for in a world-class quadruple. Otherwise, clean and quite palatable.
A dark brown beer with a nice head. The aroma is nice-bready, toasty, dark fruit. The taste had some chocolate, toasted bread, & alcohol.

Wow, wow, wow.  Incredible beer.  It was a pleasure to not only consume this, but to share it and watch others get blown away at it as well.  It helps to ease the pain a bit of Kansas losing in the 2nd Round and blowing my brackets all the hell.  Ah well.  This beer was the tits.  The beer pours out a murky, muddy-brown body with a creamy beige smooth head.  Aroma just gives and gives....dark overripe fruits, rum-soaked raisins, dark brown sugar, light clove and even lighter alcohol.  Very vinous I thought which made it even more enjoyable just for that extra dimension.  

Dark brown sugar/molasses up front, figs/blackberry mash, woody, dusty and earthy.  Finishes with a huge spicy finale with a hint of the alcohol shortly to enter the bloodstream.  Just a beautiful, stunning beer.

Bottle 11.5oz. - Poured murky brownish red color with very thin head
Aroma -  mild red wine, fruit juices and alcohol.
Flavor - Very smooth malty taste with excellent balance of texture, taste and alcohol burn.... Excellent!!!
Palate - medium mouthfeel with average carbonation. Finish is somewhat sour and has mild alcohol burn going down.
Overall -  Fine crafted brew, easy drinking for higher ABV.

12oz bottle. Pours a very ugly murky mahogany with a small beige head. Nose is terrific with thick bready yeast and tons of caramel and cherry with a modest spice undertone. One of the most authentic ABT noses Ive come across that wasnt actually from a Belgian brewery. Clean up front with a big estery profile thats mostly dark fruit but some banana as well. What makes this one exceptional is the incredible chocolate caramel finish. This is actually better than many belgian quads. Really outstanding. Huge full mouthfeel and modest but not inappropriate alcohol burn. I really dig this despite its ugly appearance.

Bottle. Hazy brown body with a small off-white head. Aroma is  ripe fruit, spices, malt and yeast. Flavor is ripe fruit, sweet chocolate and notes of caramel. Thich texture and a very long aftertaste.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a clear dark amber to brown body with a minimal fizzy off-white head that faded quickly to a thin ring.  The nose is intensely fruity from the start, even at a slightly colder temp than Id prefer.  Tons of plum, fig, and candied prunes over heavy toffee and caramel malt.  Not a whole lot of yeast on the nose, making it smell like this wont be as smooth and round as I like for an Abt.  The flavor is actually pretty soft and well rounded though.  Intense dark fruits with burnt toffee and caramel up front.  The finish is a bit harder though, and the one thing that I dont like about this is that its very hot and alcoholic.  I never get this much alcohol flavor from a Rochefort or Westy.  It really affects the overall enjoyment and drinkability.  Full bodied with a fairly chewy texture up front, but the heavy alcohol thins it out on the finish.  Decent beer overall though, maybe with some cellar time it would tone down the alcohol a bit.
Pours amber with a beige head. Aroma is caramel and fruity esters. Flavour is caramel, fruit and alcohol.
Bottle. Small head with short duration. Color is brown. Aroma and taste are rich malt, spices, caramel, fruits, chocolate and warming alcohol.

11.5 ounce bottle.  Served in a goblet, the beer pours a brownish/red color with about a 1/4 inch tan head.  However, the small head stayed around a while, and there was a decent amount of lacing, too.  Aroma is dark fruit (raisins, figs), caramel malt, brown sugar and some apples.  The taste is similar to the aroma, but with the addition of some bananas, spice, cherries, and some nuts.  Mouthfeel/body is medium/full, its a bit coating, rich, and is well carbonated.  Drinkability is decent enough, the 10.5% ABV isnt as strong in the taste as you think it would be, but you can feel it after a little while.  I think this is a good brew, although Im not sure Id buy it too often at $5.49 a bottle.  But if youve never had it before, I still think its worth trying.

Bottled at Pikkulintu. Nose of syrop and raisins. Pale head. Slight vanilla in the nose. Slightly salty and malty vinelike taste. Slight hints of raisins in the taste. Medium hoppiness. Not too swetish.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours a hazy brown color with a medium sized beige head.  The aroma, while subdued, is caramel, yeast, bready, and brown sugar.  The flavor is caramel malts, brown sugar, and dark fruits.  This is a bit sticky and I think I agree with the suggestion that this be given at least six months to develop.  Pretty good now though.

Bottle grabbed in Vancouver BC. Pours a dark brown with a hint of red on the edges. Thin tan head that disappears with no lacing. Pretty fruity aroma with cherries but also some caramel malt. Pretty powerful flavour, loaded with malt and most of the fruit has disappeared. A little rum in the finish.

Pours out a cidery color, with a huge murkiness, the head disappeared in record time.  No lacing.  Nose is fruity, bock like with dark fruit, esters, some banana and caramel too.  Palate tastes of apples, is sugary sweet, very little hops, but not cloying, the alcohol balances the sweet yet is not present.  A bit of toffee in the background and a dry finish.  Would like to cellar one of these.

Dieu Du Ciel
Rigor Mortis Abt
Pours medium hazy brown with a thin white head. Lots of bubbles on the inside of the glass. Aroma of Belgian yeast, bourbon, and dried fruits. Flavor is slightly yeasty with caramel and dried fruits. Some alcohol on the finish. Good Abt. Dieu Du Ciel rocks

12oz Bottle. Pours a cloudy brown with only a thin layer of foam. powerful fruit and malt aroma, very Belgian like.  Raisins, dried fruit and plums.Smooth creamy velvety body with a little heat at the end. Flavor is all malt, Figs dried fruit, caramel and candy sugar. Overall a very nice Abt.
user_location: Cape Coral Waterfront Wonderland, Florida, USA

text: Bottle. Poured a murky red-orange color. The head was fluffy and off white with good retention and lacing. Pleasant aroma of clove, dry white wine, toffee, subdued cinnamon, and fleshy fruits (especially apple). There was also a fairly prominent earthy, dusty corner note and a delicate hint of horse manure (in a good way). Lots going on.  Medium bodied and sweet with a warming alcohol effect, but no alcohol burn. Velvety mouth feel, yet a bit chalky at the same time. There was a nice mix of fruit, mixed spices, and malty toffee/molasses flavors. Yum.

Pours a lovely red/brown with khaki lacing. Malty sweet nose - but other than that Im having trouble picking up a nose today. Nice abby quad taste with a crazy finish - like banana, cloves, apricot, and bubble gum. Thats a party in a glass with tons going on.

Pours clear medium chestnut-brown, with a large khaki head, very fine and lasting lacing.  Aromas of biscuit, grass, caramel, banana, and apricot.  Full bodied, sharp, and zesty.  Spicy taste initially, peppercorn and coriander, bread notes, and a hint of fruit, lightly tart mid-palate, medium bitterness kicks in briefly, some nice earthy and grassy notes, diminishing into a mild aftertaste.  Lots of elements, balanced pleasingly overall.

slightly hazy red brown, smooth fine offwhite head.
Aroma of nuts, dark fruits. aromas nicely mixed up. prunes or dates, a little booze.

Flavor is boozy, quite strong dark fruits, stil well blended, bitter from alc. The alc is too strong, You are not at all in doubt were at 10% abv here. ends  sweet dark fruity, boozy and burning from the alc. A solid pour into my large Tripel Karmeliet glass produces a three finger thick, lightly amber tinged, tan colored head.  The beer is a concentrated, burnt amber color that shows a lightly hazed, deep plum red color when held up to the light.  The aroma is not anywhere near the sweetness I was expecting.  My second smell of this though has me noticing lots of rich fruit aromatics that definitely have some sweetness to them.  Notes of raisins and figs are quite prominent and there is a touch of hot alcohol towards the finish.  A rich maltiness mixes with the dark fruit, contributing a deeply caramelized malt sugar note as well as some subtle toasted grain character towards the end.  A touch of aromatics that make me think of freshly fermenting plums.  Further inspection yields ample spicy clove notes, a touch of white pepper, some woody allspice,  .  At times the beer comes off as being savory, despite the fruity and sweet spice notes.  This definitely has a complex, well integrated nose; one that is clearly world class.

Somewhat sweet tasting, though not overly so, the palate is immediately engulfed by a rich fruitiness that is only slightly wiped clean in the finish by some hot alcohol spiciness.  Fruity, with a rich sweetness and even a savory malt backbone, this beer has a lot of things going on.  There is quite a bit of spice character here, though it is not more than soft and is definitely well integrated; some lightly tongue numbing clove, an allspice note, some woody black pepper and an almost oaky spiciness (it has a definite woodiness to it somehow).  For some reason the flavor isnt as impressive as the aroma, though this is still quite good.  While this is rich and somewhat thick, the beer is not overly heavy; despite its strength it has a certain drinkability that is requisite of the style.

This is a pretty nice beer, the biggest flaw is that the alcohol can be a bit too noticeable at times; it doesnt ruin the beer for me though.  Interesting, this might be quite phenomenal if not for the hot alcohol; I wish I had bought a second bottle to age a bit longer.

Palate: Medium-high, very soft carbonation with a rich, almost creamy mouthfeel and a medium-long, spicy sweet finish.
Overall: This is a spectacular brew that is highly recommended and a must try.

11.5oz bottle via trade with zathrus13. thanks, Jeff! pours a beautiful, deep cherry-wood brown with a thin, creamy light khaki head. aroma is excellent with sweet dark fruit notes of black cherry, plum, fig, and red wine with hints of yeasty funk, brown sugar, and bready malts. flavor is great as well with smooth, sweet dark malts, toffee, sweetbread up front with vinous red fruits, tart cherries, and plums through the middle with cedar wood and belgian spice notes of cinnamon and clove on the finish. palate is full bodied but crisp and bubbly with pleasant alcohol warmth and a lingering, sweet, earthy finish. overall, another great brew from dieu du ciel.

Bottle, shared.  Pours a deep brown with a small but creamy white head.  Aroma is dark fruit - raisin, plum, fig - with malt and even a bit of alcohol detectable as well.  Sugary sweetness with malt up front, though I also detected some dark fruit in there, with a fruity and sweet aftertaste.  Alcohol is there but it doesnt take away from the overall experience.  I love my quads, and this is a solid example of the style.

Reviewed 8/2/2009 (bottled):

Pours a dark brown colored body with a small creamy whitish head, somewhat lasting. Strong aroma of dark fruit, fig and plum. Some alcohol too. Creamy mouthfeel, some warmth. Dark fruit in the taste too. Some acidic bitterness. Some more sugary sweetness as it warms up. Some roasted flavors too, more as it warms.

Murky, pondwater brown with a thin (and thinning) off-white bubbly head.  Smells funky and yeasty with a little red wine/grape.  Flavors are the typical belgian mix, but with complex layers on top, red grapes, cherry, liquor, more liquor, booze, liquor...(get it?), and candy sugar sweetness.

12 ounce bottle from my summer secret Santa. Pours a dark bronze color with a thin tan head. Moderate head retention and lacing. Aroma is very malty with notes of brown sugar, bread, berries, plum, yeast. Taste is toffee, brown sugar, bread, alcohol, berries, plum, cherry, maple syrup, leafy hops and chocolate. Medium-full bodied. Slightly warm and very smooth. Very good beer. Dieu du Ciel! impresses yet again. A worthy choice for my 2300th rating.

UPDATED: APR 16, 2011 Pours a beautiful ruby amber with a thick light tan head. Aroma of lemon, Belgian yeast, ripe fruit, berry, and toffee. Taste is some alcohol, caramel and berry. Thick molasses body with a roasty finish. .... Another bottle from Savvy1982. Nice Belgian yeast-lots of dark fruit, some banana and clove- and roasty sweet malt aroma, like a buttery biscuit and I mean the flaky, buttery, southern kind. Taste is sweet with a decent amount of alcohol noticeable. Very silky smooth texture, medium thick body, soft carbonation. Great stuff, good to revisit this, thanks again for the bottle Kyle.
12-oz. poured blind. Clear and dark amber. Lightly sweet and softly nutty/smokey aroma. This was my favorite after the westy, beating St. Bernie by a point.

11.5 oz bottle rating.  Pours a dark brown with a creamy vanilla head. Huge particalia noticed while pouring.  Aromas of caramel, bread, dark fruit, vanilla.  Definitely to style here.  Very good sipper on a nice cold evening in front of the fire.  It would be fun to see how this fares head to head against some of top belgian quadrupels.  Im guessing it would hold its own.

12oz bottle from west lakeview..... pours a dark caramel and raisin mostly opaque brown with a thick fluffy very light beige head.... aroma of dark and red fruits, raisins, toffee, and some added yeast notes... flavors continue on the same path with more robust sweet toffee and roasted malt.  smooth medium to full body with softer carbonation which works well for it.  finish adds a slight spicy bitterness. a nice quad that almost rivals the midnight sun one that i had a couple weeks back but falls just a bit short of that.

One of my favorite labels of all time, so it gets a bonus point for that.  The pour was brown and cloudy into a Chimay glass.  The head was off-white and creamy but quickly receded and left little if any lacing behind.  The aroma was roasted malts and dark fruits.  Minimal yeast.  The flavor too was dominated by what tasted like roasted malts, maybe it was burnt sugars?  Again very little yeast profile.  Some old chocolate.  Medium in body with pleasant warming alcohol towards the end.
Hazy brown with a fizzy white head.  Raisin, brown sugar, and Belgian yeast aroma and taste with some floral and molasses notes.  Decent.

THOUGHTS: Very Belgian and very nice. It was like a dubbel on steroids. Hid alcohol fairly well for the ABV, but could benefit from more aging. Really tasty. This was great.
TECHNICAL: Bottle. Poured a medium to dark brown with slight orange highlights and a very small, off-white head that mostly diminished and left fair lacing. The aroma was moderate caramel malt and candy sugar; light to moderate doughy yeast; along with raisin, apple, red wine, brown sugar and alcohol. The initial flavor was sweet; while the finish was rather sweet, acidic and ever so slightly bitter. There was caramel, candy sugar, prune, raisin, yeast, more prune, brown sugar and spices. The medium body was a little oily and then dry with rather fizzy carbonation and a lightly astringent and moderately alcoholic finish.

This cola brown beauty shows absolutely no evidence of its 10.5 percent abv. The nose is rather weak with brown sugar and chocolate. Slight banana and dark fruit with a hint of chocolate.  This is an extremely well made beer with little complexity.

Bottle from Ölbutikken.

Pours dark brown red.

Xmas spice aroma and a little alcohol.
Tastes sweet of dark fruits and some chocolate.

Fantastic Dark brown pour.  Aroma is sweet, dried fruit, overripe banana, some breadiness, yeast and a bit of booze.  Flavor is intense raisin bread soaked in dark candi and sweet booze.  Id like to put one down for another year or so and see if it softens, but this is very tastey.  Warms as it goes down.  Great sipper by DDC

Bottle.  Wonderful beer, storms into my top 10. I´m quite surprised about the relative low ratings.

Red brown with medium pale brown head. Aroma sweetm drued fruits, dates, figs, after a while more and more licorice. Taste much the same sweet malt, dates, figs, and again licorice after a while. A little hopp bitterness and a very long lasting finish. I doubt I would be able to tell this beer apart from Rochefort or Westvleterns quads in a blindtasting.

I had a Chimay Bleu in the weekend and this one is so much better.

Bottle.  Poured a rich mahogany.  Nose is candied sugar and a bit of alcohol. Really nice carbed mouthful.  Nice candied sugars. Very drinkable. Nice take on the style just a slight hint of the alcohol but I really like this one

Bottle. Amber brown body with a thick creamy off white head. Very fruity aroma with notes of yeast, ripe fruit, caramel, raisins and dark molasses. Flavour is spicy, malty and very fruity. Notes of raisins, light alcohol, yeast, dark sugar and chocolate. Lots of things going on. A lovely Abt!

Bottle purchased at Buckeye Beer Engine about....oh.... a long time ago.    The pour is a nice dark hazy brown with a thin cream head.  Aroma is a slightly spicy brown sugar scent, loads of malt and none of that banana-y yeast scent of the traditional Belgian quads.  The flavor is pretty damn rich, lots of soft chocolate notes, nothing too overdone, and all this sweet caramelized sugar flavor to it, without a hint of burnt notes or anything to spoil it.

341ml bottle. Nice brown pour with a thin white head. Sweet malt, dark fruit, some citrus and, dare I say, I caught a hint of vanilla in the the aroma. Big body, sweet malt, dark fruit, brown sugar, some citrus and an alcohol bite on the end. Really good brew.

Ruby brown hue with a nice creamy tan head.  Smell is superbly rich with notes of dates, and sweet hints of dark berries.  Taste is nicely complex with malt, butterscotch, caramel, brown sugar, and figs.  Abv is well hidden, and the texture is smooth.  Overall, I think this is my favorite stateside abt.  I must also mention the exquisite bottle art ... certainly adds to the ambience of the experience.  Definitely a repeater.

Mahogany brown with a fizzy head that dissipates quickly. Aroma is rather sweet, with caramel, pecan, lemon, and a hint of something minty. Very rich flavor, with lots more caramel, butterscotch, lemon. Boozy finish, but very smooth and refreshing. Highly recommended.

We were recommended this beer by our "Beer Connection" and it was terrific.  Lots of caramel flavor with a nice after touch that makes it very smooth.  Not a lot of hops but the high alcohol content will help keep you warm.

Bottle, has a hazy-cloudy red-brown pour with color of red rose petals at the edges, 
gave a head of light tan bubbles, the head collapsed to a thin cover, slow effervescent bubbles made an island in the center of the cover and I could see tiny bubbles climbing their way up along the sides, left some nice bubbly lacing on the glass, aromas of dark fruit, raisin, figs, dark bread, dark brown sugar and alcohol sweetness, there are some faint citrus-cinnamon and pepper spices on the nose to, I found that it helps to let this ale warm-up to really enjoy the full aroma, 

flavors of brown sugar and dark bread sweetness, raisin, prune, faint chocolate, I got a little cherry flavor when the ale almost reached room temperature, has a peppery finish with alcohol warmth on the throat, 

mouth feel is close to full, some creaminess, gives a definite warmth, each sip fills my throat and tummy with a nice, gentle warmth, but this drink does appear to feel thin as the ale warmed, I thought a little more malt flavor would have been beneficial, this is a sipper kind of ale.

Bottle, bought @ Vinens Verden, Odense.
Pours deep, dark brown with a slight red hue. Wonderful looking, creamy, off-white to beige head. Stunning duration. Really a looker! Aroma is nicely fruity and vinious. Plums, pine, muscat grapes, oranges, tangerine, cranberries, oak, caramel, chocolate. Medium carbonation, great creamy mouthfeel. Very much to style in flavour, lovely fruitiness, a tad harsh viniousness, though. Plums, chocolate, yeast, coriander, dryness, cocoa, vanilla, caramel. Really a very, very good attempt at an ABT!

Pours a deep, dark amber with a thin pale brown ring of foam. Aroma of tawny port, orange muscats, light spice - wow! Very intense flavour - warm alcohol, dark fruity malt (dates, raisins). Thin lightly carbonated body. Very, very tasty.

UPDATED: FEB 10, 2010 Wow! Pours mahogany brown cloudy with thin offwhite head. Not much carbonation in this guy, but smooth as a MOTHAFUCKA! Aroma of dark dried fruit and a little touch of tannin and smoke. Flavor is sweet but clean, finishing on an aromatic tannin-esque note. 10.5% but you cant taste any of that heat until it hits your stomach.

At volo on tap. Had a few samples of this- A deep hazed dirty brown with a nice structured eggshell cap. Nose is full on stewed fruits, lots of sugars, caramel, vanilla, spices. Tastes very sweet, of Belgian candy sugars, bubblegum, caramel, vanilla, floral spices, a bit oaky. Very good. Quite drinkable for the strength. A creamy and sweet and silky finish. Excellent example of this elusive style.

(Draught at Stockholm Beer Festival, 25 Sep 2009) Dark amber colour with frothy, beige head. Malty nose with notes of dried fruit, caramel and raisins, rather vinous.
