UPDATED: SEP 1, 2007 On Tap, 30-Aug-2007 only offered in 12 ounce tulip cups.  This beer was not offered when I was there on Monday.  Eat your heart out Dorwart.......wish you were here to enjoy this!  Pours dark brown with a light tan head.  Smells of banana, bread, spice and wood.  Taste is sweet and complex.  A wonderful mix of fruit.  Some prunes and rasins come through.  Great mouth feel.  The 10% ethanol is well hidden in this gem.  This is a complimentde by a generous dose of hops.  Possibly the best beer Ive ever had.  Rather than trying another of Dieu Du Ciel!s fine selection I came back to this beauty.

Bottle from Brewpub. Been aged for a year in the bottle. was brewered and bottles in April 2006. Dark ruby color, big thick off white head. aroma is apple, lemon, fig, plum. FLavour is much of the same. No hops to speak of, but there is a lsight sweet malt. excellent quad, its no rochefort 10, but wow, still excelent!

Small light brown head... VERY nice looking cloudy red/brownish body to it... Nice malty aromas to it..molasses,  a little pepper and coriander... very nice flowery hops... Very thick , full and creamy body! Moderately bitter... Incredibly well balanced... This beer is simply astounding!
Draught.  Reddish with a beige head.  Not too fruity and the alcohol is very well blended.  Malted toffee with a cream taste which is smoother than the typical abt/quad.  A touch of aftertaste.

Bottle aged for one year. Aroma of caramel, malt and humbugs, deep copper, wears a small tan head. Flavour is alcohol, treacle and candied malt. Full bodied, a bit boozey and warming, go figure. Terrific!
It has a dark reddish color with a beige head. The taste is very fruity but with a feel of caramel and vanilla.The % of alcohol gave a special finish that gave me a good feeling.

UPDATED: JAN 22, 2010 In short: A hoppy Abt.  Excellent take on the style. 
How: Tap and bottle many times (too many times).  
The look:  Cloudy amber body topped by a medium off-white head with medium retention.
In long: Taste is a mix between dark fruits, cake malts and  a whole lot of hops.  Very fruity (plums, prunes, raisins, etc.) but not vinous, caramel, some chocolate, some creamy toffee. Somehow the mouthfeel is thin but full, like silk.  Alcohol very well hidden. Wow.  This beer is now bottled and being able to drink this at home anytime I want makes me as happy as Dick Cheney when gas hit $70/barrel.
Ruby foncé, bon collet. Arome torrifié de malte et de réglisse. Goût dépice sucré et légèrement alcoolisé, arrière goût réchaufante.

Dark mahogany color, with reddish highlights, and a creamy tan colored head, yeasty nose, with bready dough, raw crystal malt, caramelized malt, hint of spicy vanilla, with a candied fruity pruney note in the aroma follows through on a full-bodied palate with a yeasty, fruity raisiny, and plums fruitiness, with a caramelized malt, with a sweet warming character, leading towards a sweet raisiny winey alcoholic finsh.

On tap at the brewpub. The body was dark brown with a lot of ruby. This also had a light frothy khaki clored head. The aroma was caramel with almonds vanilla and prunes. The taste was sweet caramel with some pears. There was some raisin. Smooth for the high abv.

Finally entering my rating from the sampling provided by cquiroga and oliver_mtl.  You guys are fantastic for sharing this!  Dark brown and hazy, good sized head.  Very fruity aroma, sweet apples, prunes, raisins, molasses, maybe some other dark fruits.  Big dark-fruity and sweet malty flavors - more prunes and some plum, figs, maybe some raisins, chocolate and sweet toffe.  Fairly full body - good for a quad, and very nice mouthfeel and rich.  Wow was this excellent.

RBSG 2005.

Head is mostly lasting.
Body is dark brown.

Aroma is moderately malty (chocolate, caramel), with notes of plum, vanilla, and raisin.

Flavor is heavily sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter.
Finish is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, moderately bitter.

Medium to full body, velvety texture, lively carbonation, moderately alcoholic.

Solid rendition, rich and tasty.

A 2 year old bottle at the brewery. Pours a med amber with a lightly fizzy head and none of the belgian lacing that I expect. The aroma is heavily of dried fruits, raisins, plums and alcohol. The body is a bit thin. The flavors reflect the aromas but the heat of the alcohol gets in the way. I have the samy problem with the belgian strains in my brewing. You want them to develop all those beautiful esters but you have to keep the polyphenols in check. I also think this bottle might have been past its prime.

Thanks to cquiroga and Oliver_MTL for sharing @ the PP fest.  Hazy amber-brown color with a medium sized off-white head.  Sweet aroma with apples, brown sugar, and light alcohol.  Flavor was sweet and nutty with toffee and fruit.  The mouthfeel was thick, full and slick.

Yet another Ratebeer shared beer. Thanks to Olivier_MTL and cquiroga for this one. This Belgian quad pours an orange gold color from a hand bottled bomber. Medium sized white foamy head. Aroma is brown sugar and candi sugar. Medium to full bodied quad. Malts are caramel and sweet, Very spicy tasting. Lots of brown sugar. Bright yeast. Lots of dark fruit flavor. Very nice beer. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly sweet.

UPDATED: JUN 18, 2006 Deep clear brown ale with a reddish hue and a thick moka head, creamy. Sweet candy sugar aroma with notes of fruity bubblegum and light alcohol. Sweet malt with light lactic notes, oranges, molasses. Rich and smooth bodied with nice alcohol burn in finish. Jan. 2005. 8-4-8-4-15 
Brown ale with beautiful reddish burgundy hues, and a thin off white head. Estery berries in aroma, with light vanilla, light candy sugfar and alcohol. In mouth, a rich candy sugar with notes of anism coriande, orange, some caramel and a warming alcohol. Muium! On tap, June 17, 2006. 8-4-8-4-16

Thanks to Olivier_MTL for sharing this at the Pizza Port Strong Ale fest.
Dark brown, with a nice head, the flavors of sweet, dark fruit dominate. This would make a monk drunk
Had on bottle at pizza ports strong ale fest.  A dark brown ruddy pour with a large head.  Heavy malt crossed with strong belgian yeast, yum!
A deep red beer with a small orange head. The aroma is sweet and dominated by berries - of which cowberries stand out. The flavor is also sweet with notes of wood, cowberries, and cranberries.

Had to have this one for its name, it just sounds evil!! Pours a dark burgundy with a light tan head with not much retention but good lacing. Aromas of dark fruit, mostly what seemed to me like concorde grapes, with the flavor being much of the same but slightly smoky. Very smooth, Ill have to try it again sometime!!"

draught. deep brown-mahogany body with a medium off-white head. aroma of dark fruit, raisin, and faint alcohol notes. flavour starts with rich chocolate malts and warm alcohol. dark fruit makes an appearance and the body is sometimes sweet. very tasty.
Robe brune aux reflets rouges surmontée dune mousse blanche qui sestompe. Arômes de raisins et de sucre brun. Saveurs de vin, de raisin, dalcool.

Verre de dégustation de 4 oz. à la brasserie. Arôme: Odeur de prunes, de caramel et de fruits sechés. Apparence: Couleur ambrée foncée. Aucun col. Aucune bulle. Aucune dentelle. Saveur: Goût de caramel, dalcool et de fruits foncés. Long arrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture dalcool. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Arrière goût dalcool pétillant. (Rating #272)

Bottle at the brewpubMahogany color, thin off-white head and small lacing. The nose is strong with alcohol, fairly nutty with some caramel malts and a bit of cardamom or wet dog, I cant tell. The flavor is lightly hinted towards cardboard but malty and rich at the same time. The finish is mild, not too impressive.

Pours brown with some floaties present when held up to the light.  Smells of a Ye Olde Pepper Mill with some very nice chocolate and cherry notes.  Tastes of pluots, raisins, blueberries, rasberries and soda bread.  Very complex and well developed.

RBSG 05.  #48 bomber. Jan 2005 bottle- said 10.5%.Dark cloudy brown with a nice off white head.  Aroma is fruity with lots of esters, some plum, raisin, ripe apple, and figs. Also a good thick malty backbone of dark crystal, some munich and some toasted malts as well.  Probably special b used. Flavor is some plum, raisin, scotch, oak, earthy, woody, caramel, toffee, and molasses.  The end is moderately bitter.  Smooth creamy and medium thick mouthfeel.

deep dark brown with ruby hints, fluffy beige head.  beautiful looking beer.  aroma of jelly candy, chocolate, dark bread, yeast, booze, currants and sweet malt.  flavour has plums and tart dried fruint, dark bread, sweet caramel, candy, brown sugar and booze.  a sweet, drunk belgian.  very nice.

Tried in January, again in July. Hazy red/brown with a short tan head. Aroma of chocolate, bready malts, fruit and booze. Flavours were nicely to style with the alcohol hiden behind a nice layer of raisins, grape, caramel, some nice toasted malt and cherries. I would like to have had more of the bottled version as it seemed a little quieter on tap.

Bottom of the bottle...RBSG2005... Murky, mud-colored ale with a small, frothy, beige head. Good retention. Aroma is breadsy and malty with notes of caramel, dried plum, dark raisins, pear, bubble gum and red wine. Malty, fruity flavor. Medium sweet. Mild alcohol warmth. Full-bodied and very creamy with medium carbonation. Finishes with plum, caramel and alcohol. Terrific take on the style!

07.09.05  January 05 bomber, RBSG.  Dark burgundy, tall tan head is rocky and fading.  Aroma is woody, canned fruit salad juice, mildly vinous, bubblegum, maybe a touch metallic.  Flavor bursts with old fruits - pear, apple, cherry.  lOts of alcohol present, especially in finish and somewhat burning.  Not as complex or rich as hoped, but very nice.  Its missing that yeasty something that would convince me its Abt, and not just another quad.

RBSG bottle #48
Average sized frothy tan head.
Dark amber colored body.
Sweet dried fruit aroma. Flavor follows the aroma with some alcohol added.

Bottle RBSG05.  Spicy, peppery, sweet-honey aroma with some earthiness present as well.  Transparent ruby/amber color with a tan head.  Sweet, honey-like flavor turning very roasted and slightly vinous  Roasty chocolate notes in the finish.  Nicely done.

First touch is smooth, then the harshness of the wood explodes across the palate.  Like licking an oak barrel.  Aroma is a complex mixture of berries and nuts, with a lovely woody hop and yeast finish.  More of the same oak-like harshness detracts from what would be a solid beer.

UPDATED: JUL 21, 2005 Pour was ruby brown with a thin dense tan head...smell was sweet dark fruits...grapes, prunes...yeast and alcohol...taste was also similiar...dark fruits with the addition of plums...a great alcoholic finish cleans out the fruits nicely...finished  a little creamy...

2005 RBSG - 660ml Bottle bottles in early 2005.  Vineous aroma, sweet and malty.  Sugary sweet with raisin, plum and dark pit fruit.  Smooth, smooooooth.  Some alcohol burn noted in the middle, however nicely sweet.
RBSG 2005 at DDC: Poured brown with a thin tan head. Mild citrus aroma, dark fruits also. Moderately sweet flavor with raisins and plums. Light wood notes and big alcohol. Good.

2005 RBSG Montreal Saturday. 2005 bottle at the brewpub, 10.5% abv. Red amber colour with a frothy tan coloured head. Pine, grapefruit pith, caramel, and orange peel aroma. Caramel, orange peel, grapefruit, pine, and alcohol flavours. Medium to full bodied, warming mouthfeel.

UPDATED: NOV 14, 2006 RBSG 2005... Poured a hazy reddish brown color with a light tan head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of yeast, dried fruits, apples, bananas, caramel, nuts, and alcohol.  Taste of cherries, grapes, caramel malts, smoke, light citrus, and alcohol.  Really freakin nice!

January 2005 bottle sampled at the brewpub on 7/9/05: Transparent deep amber pour with a nicely lacing cream-colored head.  Body is full and sweet with a solid Belgian maltiness and good light fruit with nice yeasty authenticity. Good dark, toasty malt presence echoes a touch of candi sugar.  This seems like it would age quite nicely.

Murky orange color (I was the last one to drink the bottle so this is understandable). Oranges, spice and whisky notes elude from the nose.  Thick heavy malty mouth, earthy, peaty, full bodied and smooth. Warming alcoholic, spiced finish. Nice, but not overly complex.

TAP: Sweet apricot and date aromas, lovely dark auburn color, low head. Caremelly heavy malt body with tastes of syrup. Brandy-like at times, wine-like at others. Low hop bittering. Thick body with a warming alcohol effect after the swallow.

on tap at DdC, poured a deep brown color with a tan creamy head.  aroma was fruity, almost a red wine or a bourbon smell, tough to tell exactly in the pub.  malts and carmels control the taste, with hints of hops on the end, along with a little bit of hops and some wine tones.  all the flavors were perfectly balanced from beginning to end as part of a medium to full body.  other than the peche mortel, this was the best beer at the pub during my visit, and this is the one i went back for another round of after the sampler was gone.

On draught 2/25/05 at the Moan and Dove, Péché Mortel release party.  Served in a tumbler between 47-52 degrees.J.F. said this was brewed in September 2004.  Dark brown color, with what seemed like some violet tinges around the edges.  Beige colored head is gone by the time I carry my glass from the bar to my table.   Aroma of lightly tart/sour yeast, dark concord grapes, hints of burgundy wine and just a tinge of dark chocolate and light caramel.  Seems VERY fruity and tart for an abt. . .Flavor is equally strange, with more fruit phenols and grapeskin notes.  Lightly dry/sour yeast does not seem to go well with the above-average carbonation and only medium body.  Sweetness begins to grow on the palate, with plenty of dark candi sugar and light chocolate notes.  A hint of alcohol, more yeast and fruit round out the finish.  Certainly an interesting ride along the palate, and my first thought was that maybe it was just too young and needed more aging, but the body isnt all that big to stand up to serious aging.  I definitely finished my glass, though I cant say I loved it.
Dark, ruby with decent head. Grape aroma with good balance between alcohol and deep malt. As the beer warms up, so do you!

I was never impressed by Rigor Mortis ABT but this time I hit the jackpot with this new batch, here we go ... Pours a dark brown color with ruby highlights, thin off-white head. Subtle aroma of rich dark malt, chocolate and alcohol. Very good flavor of rich, dark malt, chocolate and alcohol. Medium body, creamy texture, soft carbonation. Hmmmm very good !

Aroma:light fruity aroma.
Appearance:Red amber with a big head.
Flavor:Fruity very small taste of caramel,alcohol.

Dieu du Ciel was kind enough to age this bottle for 1 year for us: Dark brown with a strong frothy bubbly lasting head. Rich sweet caramel apple banana yeasty aromas. smooth with no evident alcohol once again - seems to be something this wonderful brewpub is good at - and various mouth-coating flavours of caramel ad apples and malts and maybe a little chocolate too. Lingered nicely but with perhaps a touch too much sweetness throughout - could have been a touch more balanced. Dont get me wrong though...its still worth having.

UPDATED: OCT 8, 2004 1 year old bottle aged at the brewpub.  Brown in colour with a beige coloured head.  Aroma was very yeasty with apples bananas and caramel.  Flavour was quite sweet, malty, some chocolate, very thick mouthfeel.  Large body, high carbonation and lots of alcohol.  Finished with a mild bitterness, very dry.

On tap @ the Pub-9/11/04-Nearly flat, very low carbonation for a belgian.  Extremely sweet and not very complex.  Probably the least of the 8 beers we tried. Would have loved to had the tripel, but it wasnt avail.

2 years of age. Opaque dark amber body with reddish glints and beige lasting head. Aroma is dominated by tobacco and roasted malt, but also carries some chocolate, coffee and nutty hints. Its complex taste is liquorous and smokey, with evident notes of toffee and brown sugar. Alcohol is well hidden. This is a very nice Quadrupel.

UPDATED: OCT 18, 2008 2008-10-17. Rich dark amber brown body, modest tan head. (4+) Aroma is rather spicy, which I did not expect - didnt remember it having that spice character in the past. Touch of malt. Earthy malt with just a brief touch of lemon, sweet malt core but spice is dominant for me. Smooth average plus to medium bodied palate. (3+) Solid. 7/4/7/4/15 - 3.6 Tap @ Volo Cask Days 2008

RBSG 2005. Dark brown body, moderate off white head. Sweet alcoholic nose with plenty of malt reinforcements. Typical quad profile, (?) sweet sugary malt with a moderately alcoholic finish. Medium bodied palate is quite smooth but I greedily crave for it to be more robust yet. 7/3+/7-8/3/15

Original Rating October 2003. Pours dark ruby colour with no head at all. Sweet and malty aroma, with hint of alcohol. Sweetish malt flavour with notes of fruit and raisin. Bit thinner body than I had hoped. 6/3/8/2/17
(Draught) Pours headless with a deep amber body. Nose of whiskey. Flavour of sweetened malt and whiskey with a slight barleywine je ne c'est quoi? But it is only 8.5% ABV. Very Good.

Clear red-brown body with small beige head.  Aroma is sticky sweet and rich, malty, caramel, plum/raisin, alcohol.  Taste is strong, sweet, rich, fruity (plum/raisin), caramel, finishing with alcohol warm/burn.  Full body.

UPDATED: OCT 25, 2007 One year old bottle: Cloudy pale bronze coloured. Malty nose with notes of dark fruits, plums, original Grenade apples. Good mouthfeel, warming. Malty in mouth, almost vinous, but not quite, roasted caramel, chocolate. I enjoyed the finish, but it was perhaps a little unbalanced on the sweet side. Strongly recommended.  Its about time that I update this rating. In the last three years, this has only gotten better. Absolutely luscious maltiness, soothing. It goes straight to your soul and is constantly a highlight of their anniversaries where some aged bottled are popped opened. Hopefully it is bottled someday. Bumping from 3.9 to 4.4 and it may reach higher eventually. A grapey cake of great complexity.

UPDATED: JUL 12, 2005 Fruity sweet aroma with some maltinesss and yeast apparent. Nice thick head on a clear dark amber body. Good malty fruity flavour with some bubblegum tones that becomes very sweet toward the finish. Alcohol warming very apparent. Good full body and smooth mouthfeel. On tap.

Hazy burgundy; eye-opening aroma of sweet malt, flowers, honeydew melon, alcohol, treacly malt, green peppercorns, blood oranges and slightly rotten grapefruit.  Warm, soft palate shows yeast, Special B (or its Dingemans equivalent, anyway), raisin bread, merlot.  There is a light hit of alcohol.  Finishes with a sweet malt/dry alcohol showdown. Sublime.

#24
Nice thick head, dark amber. Appearance - presented very nicely. Sweet aroma, sweet and alcoholic. To sweet, but I had more unbalanced Belgians.

Clear reddish-brown, strongly spicy aroma with subtle sweetness.  Medium carbonation, great thick mouthfeel, complex toffee-anise-orange flavors, creamy and smooth ending.  From an August '02 bottle served by the brewer.

UPDATED: SEP 15, 2009 First bottled batch:
Caramel malts support banana esters and baccate fruitiness in a perfectly conditioned body, ending in doughy yeast, peppery alcohol and spicy hop bitterness. Not as chocolatey as I remember older brewpub batches to have been, but still a mighty fine example of the style.
(Fresh) : In the bosom of the chocolate giantess lies chunks of nougat floating on a rich river of molasses, from which spurt delectable cherry alluvions...An affable and lovely peppery red wine embryo quietly slides out from its warm caramel womb...In a few years, we will revel in its grandeur...
Ƒ-year-old bottle) :  Tons of subtle roasted chocolate and fruity complexities interplay in a rather thin body, ailing for the style...A young, meditative apprentice quietly learning from its Trappist masters...

2005 and 2006 batches: this is just getting better and better folks. Palate is to die for, flavors are all prominent and balanced, this is now near greatness for the style. Rounder than Rochefort 10,  Westy 12, St.Bernardus Abt, etc. yet as classy, complex, and soul-warming. If they ever bottle this, I wont need to stock up on the aforementioned deities nearly as often.

Dark brown with ruby hints, very little head.  Aroma of plums, roasted malt, a bit of caramel and alcohol.  Thick body, chewy, chocolate, plums, grapes and warming alcohol.  Theyre gonna age this beer for a year now.  I cant wait to taste how it turns out.  Lots of potential and already a really good beer.
